Quantum mechanics is a theory of continuous linear operators between Hilbert spaces. This paper provides a purely categorical characterization of this theory. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This addresses a question about the mathematical foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. Although the evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we report the results of a comparative analysis of the genomes and transcriptomes of two distantly related myxozoan species and a less reduced cnidarian parasite. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Less)

The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has caused more than 50 million confirmed cases and over 1.2 million deaths worldwide. The virus responsible for this pandemic, severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), is able to evade the antiviral action of the immune system by blocking IFN signaling. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to block the nuclear import of IFN-stimulated genes by directly interacting with the Nup98-Rae1 complex, which is involved in the docking of the karyopherin/importin complex. Our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the antiviral action of the immune system and could be used to develop new antiviral strategies. Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by the middle of the 21st century, and the demand for food is expected to increase by 60% to meet this demand. This study shows that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially in the coming decades, and that this variability will be much larger than the variability of climate. This will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year in the world’s major maize-exporting countries. This will have important implications for global grain trade and international grain prices, especially for the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes.

The coexistence of species in a world of limited resources is a fundamental question in ecology. Niche partitioning is one mechanism that can facilitate coexistence, but it is difficult to measure because it requires species to be identified at a taxonomic resolution that is not possible with traditional methods. We used DNA metabarcoding to identify species-level diet composition for seven large mammalian herbivores in a semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between species, even when they were similar in body size and digestive physiology. This suggests that trophic categorizations based on broad-scale trophic guilds may be misleading, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results have implications for our understanding of the mechanisms that promote biodiversity and the management of large mammal populations. This article is protected by copyright. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. However, the length of the crisis is expected to vary widely, with some businesses expecting to remain open for months. Many small businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey. Finally, the majority of businesses plan to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act, but many anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the size-selective sinks of floating plastic debris in the open ocean. We also show that the global load of floating plastic debris is comparable to that of the oil pollution.

The solar system is the only place in the universe where we can study the origin of the elements. The solar system is also the only place in the universe where we can study the origin of the elements in the interstellar medium.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries.

The ability to reproduce is the most fundamental of all biological functions. In this study, we show that the ability to reproduce is also the most plastic. We show that the ability to reproduce is the most plastic of all biological functions.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the brain. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, a form that is known to be neurotoxic. Our results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of MSA and other synucleinopathies.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the interface between the circulatory system and the tissues of the body. It is the most numerous cell type in the body and is responsible for a wide range of functions including control of blood pressure, regulation of inflammation, and control of blood flow. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell type that is able to process and integrate information from multiple sources and coordinate its responses. This is achieved by the presence of a network of cells that are connected to each other in a way that allows for rapid and efficient communication.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been a major public health crisis, and the data needs of the public health community have been enormous. We have developed a data infrastructure, the COVIDcast API, that provides a common interface for accessing a wide range of data on the pandemic, including both traditional public health surveillance signals and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This infrastructure is intended to empower the public health community to track the pandemic, to conduct research, and to inform public policy.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes, such as the control of heart rate and blood pressure, the transmission of nerve impulses, and the regulation of muscle contraction. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel, where the specific ion is allowed to pass through. The selectivity filter is also the most important site for the allosteric communication between the different domains of the channel.

The gut microbiome of herbivores is a complex ecosystem that is influenced by the host and the environment. This study focuses on the role of anaerobic fungi in the gut microbiome of herbivores and the potential for these fungi to produce natural products that could regulate the composition of the gut microbiome. The results of this study provide a foundation for the discovery of natural products from anaerobic fungi and the potential for these fungi to be used as a source of therapeutics.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in determining social rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate in a social encounter, directly influences social dominance and that this effect is mediated by the nucleus accumbens, a brain region involved in reward processing. We also identify a key role for brain energy metabolism in the nucleus accumbens in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This work may also have implications for the understanding of the role of the nucleus accumbens in addiction and depression. (PsycINFO Database Record

The design of mechanical devices with complex and programmable behaviors is highly desired for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design multifunctional devices with complex and programmable behaviors. The strategy is based on the inverse design of composite structures that are digitally synthesized through a multimaterial design of experiments approach. The digitally synthesized structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication and heteroassembled into architectures that exhibit highly complex yet navigable responses. The proposed strategy can be utilized to design multifunctional devices for a wide range of applications. It can also be extended to design multifunctional materials with desired behaviors.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-binding protein of erythrocytes. The hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythrocytes is developmentally regulated, with fetal hemoglobin (HbF) being expressed in the fetus and newborn and adult hemoglobin (HbA) being expressed in adults. Here we show that the mRNA-binding protein IGF2BP1 is expressed in human erythroid tissues and is developmentally regulated, with a nearly complete reversal of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern in erythroid cells in which IGF2BP1 is overexpressed. This reversal is mediated by reduced expression of the transcription factor BCL11A, which is known to be important for the expression of HbF. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This knowledge may be useful in the development of therapeutic strategies for hemoglobinopathies and other hemoglobin disorders. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation, in cancer cells. This resistance is mediated by mutation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis, which is highly frequent in cancer, and is associated with transcriptional activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. We also identified a therapeutic strategy that can overcome this resistance, which may be useful in the development of new cancer therapies. (Read more)

Hypertension is the most common risk factor for heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of the treatment of heart failure. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are the voltage-gated L-type Ca2+ channel (Cav1.2) blockers (LCCBs). However, the use of LCCBs is associated with an increased risk of heart failure. Here, we show that LCCBs activate STIM/ORAI-mediated Ca2+ entry in vascular smooth muscle cells, which is required for the development of vascular remodeling. Our data indicate that the use of LCCBs should be carefully considered in patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling. This study may help to reduce the risk of heart failure in patients with hypertension. (PsycINFO Database Record

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal forest in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP has not yet been successful in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. We also show that the creation of early-seral ecosystems has not been a substitute for the loss of older forests.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge for the medical community. In this work, we present a computational approach to design new antibiotics. The design strategy is based on the prediction of the physicochemical properties of the compounds, their binding affinity to the ribosome, and their solubility. The best candidate was tested in vitro and in vivo, and it was found to be active against antibiotic-resistant strains. The best compound designed by us is more active than telithromycin, a clinically used antibiotic, and it is more soluble and has a higher binding affinity to the ribosome than the latter. The best compound designed by us is also more active than the other compounds in the clinical pipeline. The compounds designed by us are promising candidates for the treatment of infections caused by multidrug-resistant pathogens. This work is a step toward the development of new antibiotics. We introduce a new network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters than popular existing architectures. The proposed architecture is based on a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is applicable to a wide range of problems, and we demonstrate its effectiveness on several segmentation problems. The code for the proposed architecture is available at https://github.com/yannickdelouille/dilated_conv_net.git.

The climate of the tropics is a key driver of the evolution of life on Earth. The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa.

The use of electronic devices before bedtime has become increasingly common, but the effects of this practice on sleep and health are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device for 1 h before bedtime suppresses melatonin, phase-delays the circadian clock, and reduces the next-morning alertness. These effects are likely to be due to the short-wavelength–enriched light emitted by these devices, given that artificial-light exposure has been shown experimentally to produce alerting effects, suppress melatonin, and phase-shift the biological clock.

The Younger Dryas boundary (YDB) is a key event in the Earth’s history, and one or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope ratios of the magnetic grains and microspherules from the YDB sites are consistent with a terrestrial origin, and the rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the magnetic grains and microspherules indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America.

CTLA-4 is a well-known negative regulator of T cell activation, but its role in the development of autoimmunity and the mechanisms underlying this are not fully understood. Here, we show that the deletion of CTLA-4 in adult mice leads to a spectrum of autoimmunity, which is not observed in congenital deficiency. This indicates that the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity is not limited to the early stages of the disease.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of this diversity remains poorly understood. We show that the evolution of beetles is linked to the evolution of plants, and that the evolution of their diet is linked to the evolution of their genes.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

We report the results of a large-scale experiment in which we manipulated the size of the population of models that participants could learn from. We found that larger populations did not enhance the cumulative cultural evolution of paper planes. This finding is important because it suggests that the size of the population is not the only factor that determines the extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution. Our results also highlight the importance of trial-and-error learning to the innovation and adaptation of artifacts.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is the APOE genotype. APOE is a lipid-binding protein that is highly expressed in the brain and is involved in the clearance of senescent synapses. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also found that APOE alleles affect the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses in the brain, which may contribute to the increased vulnerability of synapses to complement-mediated neurodegeneration in APOE4. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, and they suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis is consistent with the observation that APOE4 is associated with increased risk of stroke, which is also mediated by complement-dependent mechanisms.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is the densest part of the planet. It is a key to understanding the formation of the Earth and the core–mantle boundary process. However, the formation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. This study provides a new perspective on the inner core formation by revealing the nucleation mechanism of the inner core.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are well known, the effects of acute marijuana use on the brain are less well understood. Here, we show that the brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), is reduced in marijuana abusers, which is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability. These findings suggest that the reduced reactivity to methylphenidate in marijuana abusers might contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the human brain is the only known site of language development. Despite its importance, the brain’s language system has remained mysterious, in part because of the difficulty of studying it in humans. Here, we show that artificial neural networks, a type of machine learning model, can predict neural responses to spoken sentences in humans with high accuracy. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing in the brain shapes its representation of language.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major breakthrough in machine learning, but it has been plagued by instability. We show that this instability is due to the fact that many problems in scientific computing are well-conditioned, meaning that there exist stable neural networks that can solve them. We introduce a theory of stability for neural networks and show that only a small number of layers are needed to solve well-conditioned problems. Our results have implications for the design of neural networks and the development of scientific computing methods.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a lack of transparency in the early stages of the pandemic, the politicization of science, and the spread of misinformation. However, the most common explanation for the public’s lack of trust in science is the inability to understand exponential growth. This explanation is based on a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago, which has been cited more than 1,000 times in the scientific literature. However, the experiment’s design flaws have been overlooked, and the study is now widely used as evidence for the public’s inability to understand exponential growth.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two species of bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which have diverged little in the last 13.9 million years. This study shows that the two species have retained many of the same genes, and that the genes that have been lost are similar in both. This suggests that the two species have retained the ability to cause disease in the same tissues, and that M. lepromatosis is neuropathogenic.

The entanglement dynamics of interacting quantum many-body systems is a long-standing open problem. Here, we show that the integrability of the model allows for a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. We demonstrate this result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain, and we show that it holds for a large class of models.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of more than 5 million people worldwide. The only available vaccine, developed by Pfizer and BioNTech, is expensive and requires two doses, which is not feasible for the general population. Here, we describe a vaccine that is easy to produce and requires only a single dose.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats were the main transmission pathway. However, the role of human ectoparasites, such as fleas or lice, has been overlooked. Here, we show that a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This work also provides a framework for studying the role of human ectoparasites in the spread of other diseases.

The brain is the most complex and sophisticated organ in the human body. It is also the most plastic, allowing us to learn and adapt to our environment. The evolution of the brain is therefore a key question in the study of human origins and the origins of human cognitive abilities. We show that the evolution of the brain is not only a story of size but also of the number of neurons.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin filaments are the major cytoskeletal elements in cells. They are dynamic polymers that can be assembled and disassembled, and they are the substrate for a variety of molecular motors and proteins. Actin filaments are also the targets of a number of proteins that can sever them. These proteins are important for cell motility and division, and they are the targets of many drugs. However, the molecular mechanisms by which these proteins sever actin filaments are not well understood. Here, we show that one of these proteins, cofilin, can sever actin filaments in a mechanical context. We show that this mechanochemical mechanism is critical for cofilin to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the action of cofilin in cells and for the development of new drugs.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and weight gain.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. It is the only island in the world where the Austronesian people, who are the origin of the current population of the island, are the only indigenous people. This study provides a detailed picture of the human history of Madagascar, from the origin of the Austronesian people to the present day.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a new way of understanding the role of social media in our lives, and it suggests that the influence of social media on our emotions is not limited to in-person interaction.

Messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences that direct protein synthesis can be modified after transcription. One of the most common modifications, pseudouridine (Ψ), is found in coding regions of mRNA and has been shown to impact mRNA stability and translation. Here, we show that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can impede the recruitment of the elongation factor, EF-Tu, and the addition of amino acids to the growing peptide chain. We also show that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence, and that the majority of Ψ moieties in mRNAs are found in coding regions. These findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. Together, these results provide insight into the impact of mRNA modifications on protein synthesis. (Read more)

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health and social relationships. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging and well-being.

The evolution of larger body size is a defining feature of mammals. This study shows that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We show that this temperature-dependent growth is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a leading cause of infections in hospitalized patients and in the community. It is also an opportunistic pathogen that infects patients with compromised immune systems. The bacterium is able to cause disease by producing a variety of virulence factors, including toxins, proteases, and enzymes that degrade host defenses. Here we show that the bacterium uses its pili to sense surfaces and to regulate its virulence.

The presence of pesticides in surface water is a global problem that is not adequately addressed by current regulations. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation and reveals that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. The results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. However, the role of animals in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, has been largely overlooked. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer in the United States. Our findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and suggest that a proactive “One Health” approach is needed to obtain a better understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This study highlights the need for a more comprehensive approach to the study of animal reservoirs of SARS-CoV-2. (Read more)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the reasons for the proliferation of large dams in the developing world, the problems that they cause, and the solutions that are needed.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) peptide is the primary component of amyloid plaques. However, the role of Aβ in the initiation and progression of AD is still unclear. Here, we show that neurons, which are the primary cell type in the brain, are also vulnerable to Aβ and produce a variety of inflammatory factors, which are associated with the activation of microglia. These findings suggest that the accumulation of Aβ in the brain may be a major factor in the initiation and progression of AD.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still debated. Our study shows that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in the world is to be found in the Southern Levant, where the frequency of chicken bones in the archaeological record increases dramatically during the Hellenistic period. This increase is preceded by a gradual increase in the frequency of chicken bones in the Southern Levant during the preceding Roman period. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and it is not yet clear how many distinct steps are involved. This work shows that a large protein, maltose binding protein, folds through distinct steps, and that the steps are not all on the same time scale. The results are consistent with the existence of native-like intermediates in distinct pathways.

The accumulation of RNA in response to stress is a common feature of many biological systems. In bacteria, this accumulation is often accompanied by the appearance of a cap structure, which is thought to be important for the stability of the RNA. In this study, we show that the cap structure of RNA can have a profound effect on the degradation of the RNA, and we identify a protein that is responsible for the degradation of capped RNA.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. Although the immune system is the main target of sepsis, the exact mechanisms involved in the development of the immunosuppression that characterizes sepsis are not completely understood. In this study, we demonstrate that arginine, a key amino acid in the urea cycle, is a key molecule in the development of sepsis-induced immunosuppression. We also show that citrulline, a nonstandard amino acid that can be synthesized from arginine, is a promising therapeutic strategy to restore immune function in sepsis.

The biomass of the biosphere is the total amount of carbon stored in all of the living organisms on Earth. It is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They are a key step toward understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere.

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) and show that it is a scaling limit of the sandpile model. We also show that the model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts and the implications of our results for the theory of pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, spintronics, and quantum technologies. However, it is not a good conductor of electricity. In this work, we show that diamond can be metallized, and the electronic bandgap can be completely closed, without phonon instability. This opens up new opportunities for tailoring the properties of diamond. Our findings can be used to design diamond-based devices with new functionalities. They can also be used to understand the physics of metallization and the phase transition to graphite. Our work can be used to develop new materials and devices for a wide range of applications.

The study of the structure and function of peptides is a rapidly developing field of research. This work is a contribution to the understanding of the structure and antifungal activity of a unique peptide, which is expressed in nodules of the model legume Medicago truncatula and is highly diverse in sequence. The structure of the peptide was determined by NMR spectroscopy, and it was shown to be largely disordered and highly dynamic. The peptide exhibited potent antifungal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens, and it was shown to bind to bioactive phosphoinositides in vitro and to induce cell death in germlings of plant fungal pathogens. This work illustrates the antifungal activity of a structurally unique peptide against plant fungal pathogens and paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we show that the proteome of the male reproductive tract is modified after mating, and that these changes are associated with sperm viability. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the proteome of the male reproductive tract, and that these changes are associated with energy metabolism. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of the male–female reproductive interface and suggest that the male–female interface is a dynamic system that is influenced by both sexes. Our research provides a foundation for future studies of the male–female interface and the role of the male–female interface in reproductive success. (Read more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that is stored in platelets and released upon injury. It binds to the platelet surface glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα), which is necessary for the formation of platelet aggregates. In von Willebrand disease, mutations in VWF cause the disease. We show that force can be used to switch the conformation of VWF, providing a mechanism for the disease.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria, viruses, fungi, and other microbes that are intimately associated with the human body. The human virome is the collective set of viruses that are associated with the human body. This study is a comprehensive analysis of the human virome, and it is the first to provide a database of human-associated viruses. The database is a resource for researchers to study the human virome, and it is also a resource for studying the impact of the virome on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the complexity of ACI makes it difficult to be well represented in climate models. This is due to the lack of observational capability. The dual-FOV high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) is a new technique that can provide simultaneous observations of aerosols and clouds. This instrument is expected to be a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has a profound influence on the evolution of life. The temperature of the surface in turn is determined by the temperature of the surface waters, which in turn are determined by the temperature of the deep ocean. The temperature of the deep ocean, in turn, is determined by the temperature of the mantle. The temperature of the mantle is determined by the temperature of the core. The temperature of the core is determined by the temperature of the center of the Earth. The temperature of the center of the Earth is determined by the temperature of the surface of the Earth. Thus, the temperature of the Earth is determined by the temperature of the surface of the Earth.

Ion channels are the main ion conduits in the cell and are regulated by their pore gates. The K+ channel BK lacks an intracellular activation gate and shows no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its rates and extents inversely correlate with channel-open probability. We propose that the BK channel’s closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation.

Malaria is a disease that affects millions of people worldwide, and the development of new treatments is urgently needed. One of the most important steps in the parasite’s life cycle is the invasion of the red blood cell, which is the target of the parasite’s infection. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the physical properties of the red blood cell, which in turn reduces a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding would suggest that the malaria parasite is not just a mechanical system, but a physical system, and that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate invasion.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, spintronics, and quantum technologies. However, it is not a good conductor of electricity. In this work, we show that diamond can be metallized, and the electronic bandgap can be completely closed, without phonon instability. This opens up new opportunities for tailoring the properties of diamond. Our findings can be used to design diamond-based devices with new functionalities. They can also be used to understand the physics of metallization and the phase transition to graphite. Our work can be extended to other materials, such as graphene, which can be metallized, and other materials with a wide bandgap, such as silicon carbide. This can lead to a better understanding of the physics of metallization and the phase transition to graphite. It can also lead to the development of new materials and devices.

Influenza is a highly contagious disease that causes severe respiratory illness and high mortality in the elderly and immunocompromised. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. These results provide mechanistic insights into the impact of low humidity on influenza disease outcome and suggest that dry air may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza severity. Our findings may also have implications for the development of influenza vaccines and antiviral therapies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The brain is thought to build a tree-like structure of the sentence, from the beginning to the end, word by word. However, the neurophysiological evidence for this view is limited. Here, we show that the brain builds a tree of phrases, from the beginning to the end, word by word. Our results suggest that the brain uses a merge operation to combine words into phrases, and that the merge operation is a fundamental operation in the brain’s processing of language.

Axin is a key component of the Wnt signaling pathway, which is involved in the development of the embryo. Axin is a protein that acts as a scaffold, bringing together different components of the pathway. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are not only similar at the protein level, but also genetically redundant. We show that the two forms of Axin are differentially regulated on the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which confers differential responsiveness to the pathway.

Obesity is a major health problem, and the causes are not well understood. Here we show that electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus induces eating in sated animals, and that this effect is blocked by lesions of the ventral tegmental area or the peri-locus coeruleus region. These results suggest that this circuit is involved in the regulation of eating and may contribute to obesity.

Symbiotic associations between plants and bacteria are essential for the growth of both partners, but they are also a major source of crop losses. In this work, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of concept for the use of rhizopine as a synthetic signal for the control of the nitrogen metabolism of bacteria. This work is a step toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of concept for the use of rhizopine as a synthetic signal for the control of the nitrogen metabolism of bacteria.

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that was designed to reduce deforestation by facilitating transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities and incentivizing community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities that participated in the program, but the estimated effects are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause severe illness and death, and the need for a safe and effective vaccine remains. We report the design and synthesis of a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2, which is well-established as a vaccine antigen. This variant exhibits enhanced immunogenicity and cross-reactivity with variants of concern, and can be expressed in bacteria to yield billions of doses annually. This engineered RBD can be presented on a virus-like particle to reduce weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These results provide a potential vaccine antigen for global access and a tool for vaccine development.

Neuroblastoma is the most common tumor of the neural crest, a group of cells that gives rise to many tissues and organs. In the last years, we have identified mutations in the kinase anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) as a cause of neuroblastoma. Here, we show that the zebrafish homologue of ALK, DrLtk, is activated by the zebrafish homologue of ALKALs, Dralkals. We also show that Dralkals are required for the development of iridophores, pigment cells of the neural crest. Our results provide in vivo evidence of the involvement of ALK/LTK receptors in neural crest development. This is an important step toward understanding the role of ALK/LTK in human neuroblastoma.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the pathogen that causes it has been a constant threat to humanity for millennia. This study provides a comprehensive view of the evolution of plague during the formative years of its emergence, from the Late Neolithic to the Bronze Age. We show that the plague lineage that caused the Late Bronze Age epidemic in Europe was already present in the Eurasian steppe, and that the plague lineage that caused the Late Bronze Age epidemic in China was already present in the Middle East. These findings provide insights into the origins of plague and its relationship with its vector, the flea. This study also provides a snapshot of the diversity of plague in the Eurasian steppe during this critical period of development. (Less)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity (i.e., hegemonic masculinity) and their support for Donald Trump. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, we found that women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. These findings have implications for understanding the political climate in the United States and beyond.

The agricultural intensification of the 20th century has led to the widespread conversion of grasslands to cropland, which has resulted in the release of carbon (C) to the atmosphere. This study shows that the adoption of soil health management practices in annual cropping systems can mitigate this C loss and that well-managed grasslands can store more C than annual cropping systems. These findings highlight the potential of grasslands to mitigate climate change and provide a framework for the development of climate-smart agriculture.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of zoonotic viruses to humans and the development of strategies to mitigate this risk. We present a systematic analysis of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans, using a combination of expert opinion and scientific evidence. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that this resource will be used to inform research and public health interventions for the prevention and control of future viral threats.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators, but the chemical basis for this trait is poorly understood. We show that the red color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the distantly related and hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work identifies a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a chemical basis for the red color of nectar, which is a key trait for understanding the evolution of pollination. (Less)

We present a study of the genetic structure of the population in southern Germany in the late 5th/early 6th century AD. The study is based on the analysis of the genome of 11 individuals, including 11 whole genomes and 486 functional polymorphic sites. The results indicate that the genetic structure of the population in this period was very complex, with a high degree of heterogeneity in the genetic ancestry of women. In addition, the results suggest that the genetic structure of the population in this period was not homogeneous, as indicated by the presence of genetic signals of origin in southeastern Europe. Finally, the results also indicate that many alleles associated with positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe human pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results suggest that MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for cross-species transmission. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmission. These findings are important for understanding the origins of MERS-CoV and other bat coronaviruses and for developing strategies to prevent their cross-species transmission and the subsequent

We describe the use of a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate a large cohort of febrile patients in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which presaged a national outbreak. This study demonstrates the feasibility of using a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate undifferentiated febrile illness in resource-scarce settings. This approach can be used to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This study also highlights the need for coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance to better understand the regional pathogen landscape. This information is critical for the development of public health response strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The lagging strand of DNA replication is synthesized in short fragments called Okazaki fragments. The enzyme responsible for this replication is DNA polymerase δ (pol δ). In this study, we show that the human pol δ holoenzyme is not as stable as the S. cerevisiae pol δ holoenzyme. This difference in stability has implications for the synthesis of Okazaki fragments in humans.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, it is possible to evolve ribozymes that can replicate RNA, but it has not been possible to evolve a ribozyme that can replicate RNA and synthesize functional RNA molecules. Here, we report the successful evolution of such a ribozyme, which can synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and tRNA. This work represents a major step toward the creation of a functional RNA world in the laboratory.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to show that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and proximity to other attractive neighborhoods. These results are consistent with three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic health of cities.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. The clinical manifestations of severe and critical patients are similar, and the treatment is difficult. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, is effective in the treatment of severe and critical patients with COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage and mutagenesis. The ability of fungi to regulate copper homeostasis is well established, but the role of fungal natural products in this process has not been explored. Here we demonstrate that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus is involved in the regulation of copper homeostasis and has antimicrobial properties. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. These findings have implications for the role of fungal natural products in the regulation of copper homeostasis and the evolution of copper homeostasis mechanisms in fungi and other organisms. The formation of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of silica, is a unique feature of the Martian surface. The detection of tridymite in a laminated mudstone at the base of the Aeolis quadrangle, Gale crater, Mars, is a significant discovery. The tridymite is cogenetic with the other crystalline minerals and the amorphous silica, and is possibly sourced from the crater wall/rim/central peak. The amorphous silica is possibly derived from high-SiO2 glass, and the mixed-cation salts and oxides are derived from multiple aqueous solutions.

Frost is a major abiotic stress that affects the performance of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. Despite their ecological and economic impact, the geographic distribution and evolutionary impact of these frost events are poorly understood. We show that the resistance strategies of trees to late-spring frosts are region-specific, and that the ongoing changes in frost frequencies will affect the vulnerability of forests to frost damage. Our findings can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of Th17 cells in the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease is not well understood. Here we show that the development of colitis in a mouse model of transfer colitis requires the development of Th1-like cells from a subset of Th17 precursors. These results suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, which are the key cells for muscle contraction. The disease is caused by mutations in genes that encode motor neuron proteins, and also by expansion of a single nucleotide in a gene that encodes a protein found in the nucleus of motor neurons. We now report a method to convert adult human fibroblasts from living ALS patients to induced neuronal progenitor cells and subsequent differentiation into astrocytes. This method now enables rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity in ALS. This will greatly facilitate the development of new therapies for ALS.

The role of the microbiota in the transmission of infectious agents to arthropods is just beginning to be understood. This study demonstrates that a human pathogen, Anaplasma phagocytophilum, modifies the microbiota of the vector tick, Ixodes scapularis, to more efficiently colonize the tick. The pathogen induces the tick to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and the integrity of the peritrophic matrix, which is a critical obstacle for Anaplasma colonization. The pathogen also modifies the gut microbiota to facilitate the formation of biofilms, which are important for the survival of the pathogen in the gut of the vector. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the vector to enhance transmission. (Read more)

Birds are the most successful group of animals on the planet, and their origin is a topic of intense interest. This study describes a new species of bird from the Early Cretaceous of China, which adds to our understanding of the evolution of the avian tail and the origin of the short-tailed bird group.

We show that the water vapor in the stratosphere plays an important role in the climate system. This comes from analysis of observations showing that the water vapor in the stratosphere increases with the temperature in the troposphere, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of these colors are used for camouflage. In this study, we show that the color of some vertebrates can evolve multiple times, and that the color can be used for camouflage.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death. Breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) are responsible for the initiation and maintenance of metastasis. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, a m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a BCSC marker. We also show that ALKBH5 overexpression increases the percentage of BCSCs, and that knockdown of ALKBH5 expression decreases the percentage of BCSCs. Thus, ALKBH5 is a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible is one of the most widely read books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. This study shows that the source of this parchment was not abortive or newborn animals, as has been suggested in the past, but rather the use of several species of animal, including the use of skins of maturing animals of several species.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is still debated, but the timing of the event is well established. Here we provide a precise age model for the extinction and recovery, allowing a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction. This work will also help to establish a precise time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms.

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a chronic inflammatory disease of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the presence of immune complexes in the intestinal mucosa. IBD is a heterogeneous disease, and the exact pathogenesis is still unclear. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a key regulator of intestinal inflammation. We also found that RORα is a critical regulator of intestinal inflammation by controlling the balance of inflammatory responses. Our study provides a potential therapeutic target for IBD. This study also provides a potential therapeutic target for IBD.

We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein in complex with the receptor ACE2 at 8.3 Å resolution. The structure of the spike protein provides a detailed view of the receptor binding domain and the interface with the ACE2 receptor. We find that the receptor binding domain of the spike protein is highly flexible and can undergo a number of conformational changes.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced life expectancy at birth by 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry and are the key to understanding the origin of the periodic table. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms change with pressure, and we provide a theoretical framework to understand these changes. Our results have a direct impact on the understanding of the origin of the periodic table and the chemical behavior of atoms.

Fire is a key ecosystem process, but its role in climate change is poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography, rather than climate, are the dominant driver of future fire activity. This has implications for the carbon cycle, as well as for other ecosystem functions. Our results suggest that, in the absence of large-scale changes in socioeconomic conditions, global warming will continue to accelerate in the coming decades.

The mutualism between animals and their symbiotic microbes is a model system for studying the evolution of symbiosis and the evolution of the immune system. In this study, we show that the provision of a single glycan by the animal host is sufficient to regulate the activities of the symbionts and to maintain the stability of the symbiosis. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, which in turn modulate the animal’s immune system and its ability to produce light at night. This glycan-regulated symbiosis may be a model for other animal-microbe interactions.

Text data are ubiquitous, and the volume of text is growing exponentially. We need methods to identify latent patterns in text data. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). The NVDRS summarizes violent death incidents with structured variables and unstructured narratives. We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives (e.g., preparation for death and physical aggression); many of these topics are not captured by existing structured variables. We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to many domains, including social media, news, and medical records. It can also be used to identify topics in text that are not related to violence.

The Black Death, which occurred in Europe in the 14th century, is one of the most devastating pandemics in human history. The disease was caused by Yersinia pestis, a bacterium that infects rodents and is transmitted to humans by fleas. The origin of Y. pestis is still a matter of debate, but the present study provides evidence for repeated reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our results suggest that the Black Death was the consequence of multiple introductions of the bacterium, rather than a single introduction, and that the disease was not established in Europe until the 14th century.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and play a key role in the functioning of marine ecosystems. However, the population dynamics of asteroids have been declining in many areas of the world. Here, we show that the disease-induced mass mortality of asteroids is caused by a virus.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a highly heterogeneous disease, and the identification of targets for therapy is challenging. We show that a monoclonal antibody targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is effective in suppressing the growth of AML cells in xenograft models. We also demonstrate that this antibody is effective in suppressing the growth of primary human AML cells in vitro and in suppressing the growth of primary human AML cells in vivo. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Furthermore, the results provide a proof of principle for the use of antibody-based therapies in the treatment of AML.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. It is the only island in the world where the Austronesian expansion started, and it is the only island in the world where the Bantu expansion started. This study provides a detailed picture of the human history of Madagascar, which is a key step to understand the origin and the spread of the human populations in the Indian Ocean.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Interestingly, AzuC translation interferes with the observed repression of cadA and galE by the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. These findings provide insight into the regulation of carbon utilization in E. coli and the competition between translation and base pairing.
