The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our algorithm can be used to identify CDR changes that can improve the binding affinity of antibodies against multiple SARS-CoV-2 variants, including the Delta variant. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our work highlights the power of deep learning in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

Crop experts are the eyes and ears of the agricultural community, and their assessments are critical for the management of agricultural production. However, the information they provide is often qualitative and subjective, and is not easily integrated into quantitative models. We show that the US Department of Agriculture Crop Progress and Condition survey, which has been collecting expert assessments of crop status for decades, can be transformed into a continuous probabilistic variable that is statistically robust and has nation-wide validity. We demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the Crop Condition Index can be used to monitor crop conditions and provide early warnings of crop failures, and can be used to improve the accuracy of yield forecasts. This work opens up the possibility of using the vast network of crop experts around the world to provide early warnings of crop failures and to improve the accuracy of yield forecasts.

Language is a complex system that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the nervous system that is based on changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the passage of time. We show that this mechanism is suitable for the binding of linguistic features over time within dynamic memory registers. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the general public. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life. It is also one of the most studied, but the molecular mechanisms underlying the process are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is linked to the relaxation of functional constraints on the plastid genome.

The 2015–2017 drought in southwestern South Africa was the worst in the region in the last century. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of such a drought by a factor of five to six. This increase in drought risk is driven by the increase in the frequency of the La Niña events, which are more likely in a warmer world. Our results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions.

The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear test, the “Trinity test,” has been a source of fascination for the scientific community and the public. The discovery of the first quasicrystal in the world, in the sand of the Trinity test, has been a source of fascination for the scientific community and the public.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth, converting solar energy to chemical energy that is used by all life. The biosynthesis of the pigments that capture the energy is a highly efficient biological pathway. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls, has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. This work shows that the formation of the fifth ring is catalyzed by three different enzymes, and that these enzymes are conserved in plants, cyanobacteria, and bacteria.

Neuroinflammation is a hallmark of multiple sclerosis (MS), and neuroinflammation is associated with the pathogenesis of neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroinflammation is a complex process that involves multiple cell types, including microglia, astrocytes, and neurons. Neuroinflammation is regulated by a variety of factors, including cytokines, chemokines, and growth factors. Neuroinflammation is also regulated by mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) signaling, which is known to be involved in neuroinflammation. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. These findings suggest that ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. Our findings also suggest that ASK1 is a key regulator of glial cell interactions in EAE pathophysiology. We propose glial ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. (PsycINFO Database Record

The 2012–2014 drought in California is the driest and warmest on record. We show that the probability of drought years has increased in recent decades, and that this increase is very likely due to human activities.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder that is caused by the interaction of multiple genetic variants and environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and suggests a potential target for the treatment of autism. This study also provides a framework for the identification of the converging functions of other genes that are involved in the etiology of autism.

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. The results suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The store-operated Ca2+ (Ca2+) (SO(2)) channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling and homeostasis. Mutations in the SO(2) channel components, ORAI1 and STIM1, cause severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and loss-of-function mutations in ORAI1 that cause congenital bleeding disorders. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated SO(2) channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the SO(2) channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (PsycINFO Database Record

Neurodegenerative diseases are characterized by the accumulation of misfolded proteins in the brain. These proteins aggregate and spread throughout the brain, causing damage to neurons. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a model of Huntington’s disease is non–cell-autonomous, and that the spreading of aggregates is dependent on endocytosis. We also show that the release of aggregates from the cell is an important step in the spread of aggregates. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for neurodegenerative diseases.

Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, the role of bats in the emergence of zoonotic viruses is still controversial. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of bats in the emergence of zoonotic viruses and the potential of bats as a source of emerging viruses. These findings may help to develop strategies to prevent the emergence of zoonotic viruses. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is essential for cell growth. We report the discovery of a small-molecule dual inhibitor of human serine hydroxymethyltransferase 1 and 2, which blocks colon cancer cell growth in xenografts. We also report a glycine import defect in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, which is uniquely sensitive to inhibition of this enzyme. These findings provide a metabolic target for the treatment of cancer, and a potential mechanism for the sensitivity of B-cell lines to SHMT inhibition. This work also provides a rationale for the use of glycine-rich drugs in the treatment of lymphoma. Collectively, these findings provide a metabolic target for the treatment of cancer, and a potential mechanism for the sensitivity of B-cell lines to SHMT inhibition. This work also provides a rationale for the use of glycine-rich drugs in the treatment of lymphoma.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease that affects motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is caused by mutations in a number of proteins, including superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1), TDP-43, and FUS. We show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of ALS patients are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusions are caused by a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results suggest that the inclusion bodies in ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state may be a common feature of neurodegenerative diseases caused by aggregation-prone proteins. (Read more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The device can be used to study many-body physics of quantum matter, including the study of the quantum phase transition between a superfluid and a Mott insulator.

The Cretaceous period is often considered the age of dinosaurs, but it was also the age of the origin of many flowering plants. The study of the early evolution of the angiosperms, the group that includes all modern flowering plants, is poorly understood. The research presented here focuses on Montsechia, a plant that was first described more than 100 y ago. Based upon the study of more than 1,000 carefully prepared specimens, the morphology and anatomy of Montsechia suggest that it was an aquatic plant, similar to Ceratophyllum, and that it was the sister group of Ceratophyllum.

Parvoviruses are a large and diverse family of DNA viruses that cause a number of diseases in humans and animals. The most common human parvovirus, B19V, is associated with a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. Here we present the genomes of five individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Less)

Sea level is a key indicator of global change. In this study, we show that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that this acceleration is consistent with the rate predicted by climate models.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in the United States for all adults, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950. This erosion of working-class life is not limited to pain, but is part of a more general erosion of the middle class.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of enzymology. The application of NMR to the study of enzymes has been transformative, but the study of the active site, the region of the enzyme where catalysis occurs, has been challenging. Here, we show how the application of NMR to the study of crystals can provide insight into the active site and the mechanism of the enzyme.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no licensed antiviral treatment for MERS, and the available options are limited to supportive care. Here, we show that remdesivir, an antiviral drug that is approved for use in other diseases, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial of MERS-CoV infection, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of great benefit to patients, healthcare workers, and the wider community.

The mutualism between animals and their symbiotic microbes is a model system for studying the evolution of symbiosis and the development of the immune system. In this study, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by the animal host is sufficient to regulate the activities of the symbiont and the health of the symbiosis. This glycan is provided by the animal host at a specific time of day, and its catabolism is required for the development of the symbiosis and the production of bioluminescence. This glycan may be a common nutrient used by other animal hosts to regulate the activities of their symbionts.

This study shows that it is possible to reduce suspension rates in middle schools. This is a major public health problem, and it is also a major predictor of adult incarceration and unemployment. We show that it is possible to change the mindsets of teachers, and that this change can be sustained through a brief online intervention.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage and is implicated in a variety of human diseases. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis are still largely unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of alkylation on the fidelity of transcription. We found that the presence of alkylation can modulate the fidelity of transcription at different stages. The results from this study provide mechanistic insights into the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis. This work also provides a foundation for the development of therapeutic strategies to mitigate the deleterious effects of DNA alkylation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. In this study, we show that the spike protein of MERS-CoV requires sequential proteolysis to facilitate binding to cell receptors and fusion with the target cell membrane. We also show that the first cleavages of the spike protein are required for infection of human airway epithelial cells, which are relevant to lung infection. These findings suggest that the first cleavages of the spike protein are important determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is a major driver of environmental degradation and a leading cause of biodiversity loss. The food choices of the population have a major impact on the sustainability of the food system. In this study, we show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a university cafeteria had a significant impact on meal selection. This suggests that simple changes to catering practices could have a major impact on the sustainability of the food system.

The cell surface proteome is the interface between the cell and its extracellular environment. It is a dynamic and complex system, and the surfaceome is a target for cancer therapy. Here we report a systems-level view of how oncogenes remodel the surfaceome in a cell autologous fashion. We also report a method for the analysis of the glycoproteome, which is a target for cancer therapy. These studies provide a framework for the discovery of surface targets and combinations thereof for drug and biomarker discovery. They also provide a resource for the study of the surfaceome in other cell types, including cancer cells, and the glycoproteome in other cell types, including cancer cells.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global community. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein that has been proposed to interfere with immune responses. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. This work provides insight into the molecular basis of the COVID-19 pandemic and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Read less)

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a common condition in the brain. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is mediated, at least in part, by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 and cerebral edema. These findings provide a molecular mechanism for the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of cerebral edema. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The problem of selective inference is the challenge of assessing the strength of associations in a dataset that has been selected for analysis. This is a problem that is becoming more important in the era of big data. We describe some recent developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

Endothelial cells (ECs) are the most abundant cell type in the blood vessel, and their dysfunction is associated with many diseases, such as atherosclerosis and diabetes. Therefore, the generation of ECs is a promising therapeutic approach for these diseases. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce ECs remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone induces EC-like cells from fibroblasts, and that these cells can be used for the treatment of vascular disorders. This study provides a new approach for the generation of ECs and the treatment of vascular disorders. Furthermore, the use of ETV2 for the generation of ECs may be applicable to the generation of other cell types, such as neurons and cardiomyocytes.

We report the discovery of a third class of ligand for the RTKs ALK and LTK, which are involved in the development of the eye and the skin. We show that these ligands are essential for the development of the iridophore system, which is responsible for the color of the eye, and for the pigmentation of the skin.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major health problem worldwide. Although the molecular mechanisms of T2D are well-known, the treatment of T2D is still challenging. In this study, we found that STING is required for normal β-cell function and is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D. STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, contributing to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, the assay for transposase-accessible chromatin with high-throughput sequencing (ATAC-seq) and cleavage under targets and tagmentation (CUT&Tag) analyses suggested that Pax6 was the transcription factor that might be associated with defective GSIS in STING-βKO mice. Together, these data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings provide a potential target for the treatment of T2D. (PsycINFO Database Record

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and occasional pandemics. They are able to infect a wide range of species, including humans, and cause severe disease. The influenza A genome is segmented into eight fragments, which is a unique feature of this virus. However, this feature also complicates the packaging of the genome into virions. Here, we identified a mechanism that favors the packaging of two viral RNA segments into each virion. This mechanism is sequence dependent and is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses.

Atherosclerosis is the leading cause of death worldwide. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process that involves a series of events, including the activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes of vascular cells. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results demonstrate a critical role of the activation of YAP/TAZ by disturbed flow in promoting atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion development. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of atherosclerosis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the natural landscape for millennia. However, in recent decades, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially. This is largely due to the expansion of the spatial and seasonal fire niche, which has been driven by human activities. We show that human activities have vastly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire, and that the human-caused fire season is three times longer than the lightning-caused fire season. Actions to reduce the extent and intensity of human-caused wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to show that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and proximity to other attractive neighborhoods. These results are consistent with three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic health of cities.

Natural repellents are a class of plant-derived compounds that are used to protect humans and animals from insects. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in insects remain elusive. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel as a chemosensory receptor of natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study provides a molecular insight into the arthropod–plant adaptation and may help in the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help in the conservation of biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent Zika virus (ZIKV) outbreak has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The mechanisms of ZIKV pathogenesis are not fully understood, but the role of the immune system in the disease is well established. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV dynamics in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the rate of viral production is rapid, and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also show that the antiviral treatment favipiravir can reduce the time to undetectable plasma viral load from ∼5 d to ∼3 d, whereas treatment given 2 d postinfection is mostly ineffective in accelerating plasma VL loss. These results can help in the development of more effective antiviral treatments for ZIKV. (Read more)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that is often used as a proxy for the health of coral reefs. However, the underlying mechanisms are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling and energy availability. This provides a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general.

The intestinal epithelium is the main barrier between the host and the external environment. It is also the main site of nutrient absorption and immune surveillance. In the case of cancer, the epithelium loses its barrier function, leading to systemic infections and organ dysfunction. Here, we show that the intestinal tumor microenvironment triggers a regenerative response in the microbiome, which in turn triggers the tumorigenic process. We also show that inhibiting the tumor microenvironment or the microbiome can restore the barrier function of the epithelium, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis and organismal lifespan extension. Our work identifies a mechanism that can be targeted to control the activity of the tumor microenvironment and restore homeostasis. It also highlights the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. This work has implications for the treatment of cancer and for the development of new therapies to restore homeostasis in the intestinal epithelium.

Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but many patients do not respond to it. In this study, we show that treatment with chemotherapy enhances the expression of the orphan receptor tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 in breast cancer cells, which in turn enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to survive chemotherapy, to invade the extracellular matrix, to form spheroids, to engraft mice, and to metastasize. We also show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with the humanized monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab, which binds to ROR1, reduces the capacity of breast cancer cells to survive chemotherapy, to invade the extracellular matrix, to form spheroids, to engraft mice, and to metastasize. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Read more)

The start of accelerated deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is often attributed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, which is thought to have caused a change in ocean circulation and climate. We show that the start of this change is coincident with the eruption of Mount Takahe, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion. This finding suggests that the start of accelerated deglaciation was triggered by a natural event, rather than by human activities.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that the majority of catches come from regions with high levels of human population density and river discharge, and that the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security highlights the importance of inland fisheries in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. Our data can be used to inform conservation and management of river ecosystems, as well as to assess the impacts of fishing on biodiversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. Due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited. For achieving durable and high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries, the development of negative electrode materials exhibiting a large capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water is crucial. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work is expected to provide a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system that is lost in the adult mammalian CNS. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery opens the door to a new platform for the discovery of genes involved in neuronal regeneration.

Recombination is the process by which genetic material is exchanged between homologous DNA sequences, and it is essential for the maintenance of genetic diversity. In eukaryotes, recombination is also the primary mechanism for the generation of genetic variation. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, and we show that the distribution of recombination is similar to that observed in yeast and in mice.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in blood oxygen level-dependent (BOLD) signal representing a small fraction of total neuronal activity. The analysis of these fluctuations has led to the identification of a set of reproducible networks, which are thought to reflect the functional architecture of the brain. However, the functional significance of these networks is unknown. Here, we show that the dominant network in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the default mode network, whereas in Parkinson’s disease the dominant network is subordinated to a disease-related pattern. Furthermore, we show that the dominant network is deactivated during task performance, and that this abnormality is partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. Finally, we show that the dominant network is activated during cognitive tasks, and that this abnormality is present at diagnosis in Alzheimer’s disease. These results provide a direct link between the functional organization of the brain and its metabolic activity. They also provide a framework for the study of the functional significance of the dominant network in health and disease.

We report the discovery of a 5′ cap structure in yeast nuclear and mitochondrial transcripts that is modified by nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+). This cap is found on subsets of transcripts, and is not present on the majority of transcripts. We also show that the 5′ cap structure is not a pseudouridine, and is not a 5′ modification that is conserved in animals.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. We show that epigenetic DNA-methylation differences at specific loci in blood are associated with glycemia for several years during the EDIC Study. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease that affects the brain and the gut. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not known, and the role of the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato flavor is not well understood. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also show that this gene is required for the production of a single nitrogenous volatile in N. benthamiana, and that this gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit and will be of interest to researchers in the fields of plant biochemistry, flavor chemistry, and biotechnology. (Read more)

Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these two factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increases, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have implications for the design of conservation strategies and the development of mitigation policies. (Less)

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key hub in the hippocampus, where it receives information from the hippocampus and neocortex and sends information to the hippocampus and neocortex. It is also the site of formation of the hippocampal place code, which is the neural basis of spatial navigation. Here, we show that the spatial organization of neurons in MEC is strongly influenced by the animal’s behavior. This is the first study to our knowledge that examines the topographic organization of neurons in MEC during unrestrained behavior. Our results have implications for our understanding of the formation of the spatial code in the hippocampus and the role of MEC in navigation. They also provide a platform for future studies of the organization of the spatial code in the brain.

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the FT gene is not required for flowering of the host, but is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates the importance of the FT gene in flowering regulation and the importance of the FT gene in interplant communication.

The dopamine system of the brain is involved in movement and motivation. We show that striatonigral fibers originating in striosomes form highly unusual bouquet-like arborizations that target clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, these striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease.

We are social creatures, and we seek connection with others. We also seek to understand the nature of connection. In this work, we show that the speed at which people respond to each other is a robust and sufficient signal of connection. This finding has implications for our understanding of the nature of connection, and it has implications for our ability to build connection with others.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is composed of specialized cells, the sinoatrial cells (SANCs), which are responsible for generating the electrical impulse that initiates each heartbeat. The SAN is a highly specialized organ that must be able to maintain a constant heart rate in order to maintain a normal blood pressure. In this study, we show that the activity of the SAN is regulated by the activity of the sarcoplasmic reticulum, the organelle that stores calcium in the heart. We also show that the activity of the sarcoplasmic reticulum is regulated by the activity of the plasma membrane. These findings have implications for the treatment of heart failure, which is characterized by an abnormal heart rate. (Read more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, and its beneficial effects on plant resistance against abiotic and biotic stresses have been well documented. However, the role of Si in mediating insect herbivore defense responses has not been explored. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by priming of the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact in mediating insect herbivore defense responses. This study provides insights into the role of Si in mediating insect herbivore defense responses and may contribute to the development of Si-based strategies for insect pest management. The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the activation of macrophages and for the expression of inflammatory mediators. Our results suggest that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is a potential target for the modulation of macrophage activation.

Language is a complex system that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the nervous system that is based on changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the passage of time. We show that this mechanism can support the binding of linguistic features over time, and it can support the integration of information over time within the language system.

Plants are sessile organisms and are unable to deliver biomolecules to themselves. This is due to the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Here, we show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules to plants, and we demonstrate the feasibility of using DNA nanostructures to deliver siRNAs to plants and silence a gene. We also show that the gene silencing efficiency depends on the DNA nanostructure geometry and the location of the siRNA attachment locus on the nanostructure. Our work establishes the feasibility of using DNA nanostructures for biomolecule delivery to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a step toward the development of DNA nanostructures as a tool for plant biology.

Nutrient loading from small tributaries of large water bodies is often overlooked in monitoring and regulatory efforts. We show that the 6 largest tributaries of Lake Michigan account for ∼70% of the daily nutrient loads delivered to the lake. However, small tributaries exhibit nutrient loads that are high for their size and biased toward dissolved inorganic forms. This suggests that their plumes become trapped and then overlap in the nearshore zone, increasing the likelihood that they will fuel algal blooms. Our findings reveal an underappreciated role that small streams may play in driving coastal eutrophication in large water bodies.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in the presence of a strong thermodynamic forcing. We show that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environmental forcing.

We show that NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) can cause a spectrum of paroxysmal EEG abnormalities, which are thought to be caused by changes in receptor function. We show that NMDAR-Abs can change the dynamics of the cortical microcircuit, and that these changes can predispose the brain to paroxysmal abnormalities. We also show that the same changes in the microcircuit can be tolerated in the absence of NMDAR-Abs. These findings offer mechanistic insights into the circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. They also suggest that the same changes in the microcircuit can be tolerated in the absence of NMDAR-Abs, and that the paroxysmal abnormalities are a consequence of the disease state rather than a consequence of the antibodies. This suggests that the treatment of NMDAR-Ab encephalitis should focus on reducing the disease state rather than on blocking the antibodies.

The Earth system is currently undergoing a rapid warming event, which is unprecedented in the last 2,000 years. This study provides insights into a similar event that occurred during the last glacial period. We show that the warming event was accompanied by a perturbation of the carbon cycle, which is unprecedented in the last 2,000 years.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that certification has a positive impact on the rate of deforestation, but that this impact is limited by the fact that most certified areas contain little residual forest. Our results suggest that certification has not yet achieved its full potential to reduce deforestation, and that the scheme will need to be strengthened to achieve this goal.

The exocyst complex is a multisubunit protein complex that is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. The exocyst complex is conserved from bacteria to humans, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. However, the study of the dynamic regulation of the exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Read more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the genetic basis of sex determination is a key component of the evolution of sex differences. In this study, we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles on the evolution of secondary sexual characteristics in a fish species. We find that the genetic basis of sex determination in this species produces a modular interplay of sex linkage and sex limitation, resulting in a variety of morphological and behavioral traits in the four possible sexes. These results provide insight into the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by a variety of reactive species that can damage photoreceptor cells and the retinal pigment epithelium. In this study, we show that the intracellular levels of iron can influence the retina. We also show that the levels of iron can be manipulated to protect the retina from damage. These findings have implications for the treatment of retinal diseases. (Read more)

Predators are the key to understanding the structure of food webs, and the evolution of their prey. However, the evolution of predators has been considered a dead end, due to the constraints associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that the evolution of siphonophore predators has been driven by the evolution of specialized structures dedicated to prey capture. Our results contribute to understanding the evolution of predators, and the structure of food webs.

The human hand is a complex and highly specialized structure. The evolution of the human hand is a key topic in the study of human evolution. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process, and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding has implications for the evolution of the human hand and for the origin of modern humans.

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is a key metabolic intermediate. We report the discovery of a small-molecule dual inhibitor of human serine hydroxymethyltransferase 1 and 2, and show that this compound blocks the growth of colon cancer xenografts in mice. We also show that the one-carbon donor formate is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition in colon cancer cells, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. We further show that glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. These results have implications for the treatment of cancer, and for the development of new therapeutics for lymphoma. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets and dietary vitamin A adequacy. This is a significant finding given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The results have implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

Mechanization has been a key driver of the Green Revolution, which has increased food production by 200% since 1960. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction.
